body:
Top Ten Female Characters (Spoilers)

3. Carol Danvers/Captain Marvel (Marvel Cinematic Universe)

This really shouldn’t come as a surprise but Captain Marvel is one of the most badass characters in MCU. Carol Danvers takes third place due to her endless determination and spirit do accomplish what she wants. When she wants it, she gets it. Let’s be honest, sometimes we have a hard time going after what we want in our lives and who we want to be. Carol however, despite her setbacks, pulls through in the end and chooses who she wants to be for herself and no one else. The moment I saw her coming to terms with her past and what was happening to her, I felt connected to her in an instant. Let her be a reminder that no one else can be you and no one should change you into something else. Just be you. Also let’s be honest, there’s nothing wrong with being bossy. I was surprised a lot of people gave this movie crap for being “too feminist”. Like bitch shut the hell up, it’s an art and extremely hard to come up with female characters without using previous models in various media. Uncultured Swines.

summary: Captain Marvel: StarForce On The Rise - Book Review
title: Captain Marvel: StarForce On The Rise - Book Review
body:
Captain Marvel: StarForce On The Rise – Book Review

The Centum books that tie into the new Marvel Studios film releases have allowed fans to get more information on the build-up to these big events. Captain Marvel: Starforce On The Rise focuses on some of Vers adventures during her time with StarForce, acting as a prequel to the Captain Marvel movie released earlier this year.

Before Carol Danvers was Captain Marvel, she was Vers, a member of…

View On WordPress

summary: If/when they confirm Carol Danvers as a lesbian, y’all better miss me with that “first cinematic lesbian superhero” nonsense...
body:
If/when they confirm Carol Danvers as a lesbian, y’all better miss me with that “first cinematic lesbian superhero” nonsense because it’s Trini erasure and I’m not here for that. 

Carol Danvers is awesome; not being the first lesbian superhero doesn’t make her any less awesome.

reblog.comment:

summary: The guy in the deleted Captain Marvel scene was overly aggressive and here’s why:
title: The guy in the deleted Captain Marvel scene was overly aggressive and here’s why:
body:
@ijaws

https://www.slashfilm.com/captain-marvel-deleted-scene-smile/

The guy drives up next to her - he could have parked his bike anywhere in that parking lot. As he drove in, he saw a pretty blonde lady standing alone and decided to talk to her. 

He makes an unnecessary and trivializing comment about her clothes. “Nice swim suit.” No hello, no nice to meet you. Just immediately catcalling. And yes, it’s catcalling, not some nice compliment. The difference is in how you deliver it. Strike one.

Carol puts the map up quickly to create a physical barrier between the two of them. He ignores her body language, which is clearly indicating that she’s not interested. Strike two.

He says “You need a ride, darling?” That’s a double entendre - a ride on his motorcycle and a sexual invitation. Strike three. 

We’re only 15 seconds into the scene here.

He pushes down the map, physically invading her space. She glares at him - another clue he should leave her alone. He’s smiling - still ignoring her body language. Strike four - and he’s still trying to get her. 

He asks her to smile. He does not say please - he just smiles menacingly.  Again, he does not say hi, he does not say hello, he does not say how are you, he does not ask for her name. He says, “How about about a smile?”

He says he is offering to help her, but she did not ask for help or verbally agree to any help. He’s trying to set up a situation where she owes him for his help. He even wants to get her on his motorcycle, where he could take her anywhere he wanted.

She angrily moves the map away. Her voice has a nice tone, but her body language expresses annoyance. She suggests a neutral, professional interaction instead: a handshake. 

She introduces herself as Vers (not remembering her real name yet) and the motorcycle guy introduces himself as “The Don” - not Don, not Donny, not Donald - THE Don. Or maybe nobody calls him that and he’s just trying to impress Carol.

“Wow.” Carol says. She doesn’t let go of his hand. She electrocutes him with her glove instead, which seems very painful. She suggests that he hand over his jacket, his helmet, and his motorcycle and in return, she won’t destroy his hand. “The Don” immediately accepts.

“What, no smile?” she says viciously. He runs away. Carol steals an outfit off an manikin and drives off on the motorcycle. 

You really don’t see how he was being a misogynist in every little part of that interaction? He was setting up the situation even as he was driving into the parking lot. It is not NORMAL or acceptable to walk up to a strange woman who is standing alone in a parking lot and do everything that this guy did. The movie literally couldn’t be clearer about how unsympathetic he was supposed to be.

OK? Ok. Nice talking to you.

today in Nextwave: a scumbag cop gets the shit kicked out of him by Boom Boom and Machine Man, saved by Monica who is a kind and decent person and thought he was a good cop, and then fed to the community he abused for years while he whimpers and begs for mercy

summary: CAPTAIN MARVEL (2019) Grade: B Brie Larson is great and perfect for the role. She's the best right now. Had great chemistry Sam...
caption:
CAPTAIN MARVEL (2019)
Grade: B

Brie Larson is great and perfect for the role. She’s the best right now. Had great chemistry Sam Jackson. She’s great at these sutble facial expression that rely so much humor. Could have used a little more exposition on the proantagonist.

reblog.comment:
